bestBHT.bht: Hence, it is plain that our Lord's ministry did not commence with the imprisonment of John; we should have drawn that inference from Mark's express statement. The reason for the imprisonment having been given by Luke, the periphrastic past perfect indicative of βαλλω explains why John was still baptizing. This circumstance shows that these things were done before that journey of Christ into Galilee.

bhtAttempts.bht: Hence, it is plain that our Lord's ministry did not commence with the imprisonment of John; we should have drawn that inference from Mark's express statement. The reason for the imprisonment having been given by Luke, the periphrastic past perfect indicative of βαλλω explains why John was still baptizing. This circumstance shows that these things were done before that journey of Christ into Galilee. John's continued ministry despite the presence of Jesus emphasizes the importance of ministers being industrious until the end.

Hence, it is plain that our Lord's ministry did not commence with the imprisonment of John; we should have drawn that inference from Mark's express statement. The reason for the imprisonment having been given by Luke, the periphrastic past perfect indicative of βαλλω explains why John was still baptizing. This circumstance shows that these things were done before that journey of Christ into Galilee.

Hence, it is plain that our Lord's ministry did not commence with the imprisonment of John; we should have drawn that inference from Mark's express statement. The reason for the imprisonment having been given by Luke, the periphrastic past perfect indicative of βαλλω explains why John was still baptizing. This circumstance shows that these things were done before that journey of Christ into Galilee, emphasizing the importance of ministers being industrious until the end.

Hence, it is plain that our Lord's ministry did not commence with the imprisonment of John; we should have drawn that inference from Mark's express statement. The reason for the imprisonment having been given by Luke, the periphrastic past perfect indicative of βαλλω explains why John was still baptizing. This circumstance shows that these things were done before that journey of Christ into Galilee, emphasizing the importance of ministers being industrious until the end.

It is evident that our Lord's ministry did not begin with John's imprisonment, as indicated by Mark's statement. The reason for John's continued ministry, despite the impending imprisonment, is clarified by Luke. This sequence of events preceded Christ's journey into Galilee, highlighting the dedication of ministers to their work until the end.
